author: ROSLYN SULCAS
title: Boston Ballet Takes On William Forsythe’s ‘Artifact’
text:
Boston Ballet Takes On William Forsythe’s ‘Artifact’ By ROSLYN SULCAS Photo Dusty Button of the Boston Ballet in William Forsythe’s “Artifact.” Credit Rosalie O'Connor, via Boston Ballet “Step inside.” Those are the first words spoken in the first moments of William Forsythe’s “Artifact,” the full-length ballet he created in 1984 after taking the reigns at the Frankfurt Ballet, a relatively unknown German company with a conventional repertory of story ballets. The American-born Mr. Forsythe, who had spent most of his professional career — as a dancer, then as a choreographer — at the Stuttgart Ballet, was extending an invitation. Step inside into another kind of story ballet: one populated by mysterious characters, enigmatic text, severely beautiful classical dancing and a panoply of theatrical devices, like a curtain that crashes down repeatedly during a double pas de deux to Bach’s Chaconne in D minor. “Artifact” was a manifesto of Mr. Forsythe’s intent to investigate and extend the boundaries of ballet technique and conventions, and it is still an urtext in his oeuvre. It has been performed only once in the United States, in 1987, by the Frankfurt Ballet at SUNY Purchase, but on Thursday, the Boston Ballet will set that to rights, opening a two-week run of “Artifact.” “It started with a single idea,” Mr. Forsythe said in a telephone interview from Boston. “That ballet technique and tradition is transmitted by simple imitation.” Continue reading the main story The Boston Ballet performances — the first by an American company of a full-length Forsythe piece — mark the start of a five-year collaboration between the company and Mr. Forsythe. Mikko Nissinen, the Boston company’s director, last year described it as “a dream come true,” saying Mr. Forsythe “is an important modern artist and a profound American voice.” 
Advertisement Continue reading the main story That hasn’t been the prevailing critical view of Mr. Forsythe, 67, in his home country — or hometown (he’s from New York City) — where his work has frequently been criticized for its experimental and conceptual tendencies, as well as for its athletic and extreme elaborations of ballet technique. In Europe, though, he has been regarded as one of the most important creative figures in dance for close on three decades. And while Mr. Forsythe created works for important international ballet companies in the 1980s and ‘90s, the scope and extent of his work — from neo-Classical pure dance to highly theatrical, text-based pieces — has remained relatively unknown to American audiences. “Artifact” opens with a slow upstage walk, in silence, by a dancer in a gray unitard and ghostly gray makeup. The stage is bare; everything suggests we are about to see a contemporary work. Then slow piano music begins (by Eva Crossman-Hecht) and a woman, wearing a panniered 18th-century dress and a white wig, sweeps in with elaborate, baroque arm gestures. “Step inside,” she says. “Welcome to what you think you see.” Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Dressed in the spare tights-and-leotard costumes that evoke the modernist works of George Balanchine, an ensemble moves with academic precision through the basic steps of the ballet vocabulary: tendu (the leg stretching away from the body, the toes pointed to the floor); rond de jambe (circling of the outstretched leg); battement (the straight leg lifting off the floor). These are executed plainly — the dancers might be taking their daily class — but they are combined with the elegantly shifting head, hip and shoulder changes that are called épaulement, one of ballet’s most important stylistic principles. At the same time, Mr. Forsythe introduces multiple enigmas. What is the meaning of the words spoken by the elaborately garbed woman who keeps recombining the verbs “see, think, say, hear, remember, forget” in persuasive but bewildering monologues? (“Try not to forget what I am thinking, and you’ll see what I said.”) What does the soft-spoken “Man with the Megaphone” represent? Why does the curtain come down, repeatedly, on the beautiful neo-Classical drama of Part 2 that is Mr. Forsythe’s equivalent of the “white act” (the swans, wilis and bayadères that provide the pure dance sections of 19th-century ballets)? “I remember a story, and it went like this,” says the Man with the Megaphone. But we never get just one story in “Artifact.” We get the multiple stories of classical ballet: its origins in court dance; its narratives of princesses and swans; its relentless repetition of basic technical elements; its hard-working ensembles framing resplendent soloists; the way those soloists emerge from that ensemble, and like Balanchine’s dancers, are costumed identically and sparely. However wonderful an individual performance, the dancers are, in the end, anonymous servants of the art. Mr. Forsythe said that “Artifact” had been inspired by an essay in Lincoln Kirstein’s book, “The Classic Ballet,” which he read in his early 20s. “It was my first encounter with ballet history, with the idea that these codes and traditions came out of specific conditions,” Mr. Forsythe said. “It also taught me that ballet is an oral tradition; we pass it on not only visually, but verbally.” The language in “Artifact,” he said, is the language of ballet terminology. “En dehors, en dedans, the outside, the inside, remembering, forgetting; it’s what we say in class and rehearsal every day.” Mr. Forsythe has worked intermittently on “Artifact” over the last 30 years, and he has substantially changed Parts 3 and 4 while in Boston. “The ballet’s early trajectory was powered by what I observed at New York City Ballet in my youth, in the ‘70s,” he said. “It had a particular kind of vitality, and this is one of the most important things. Ballet is not a sleepy or soporific art, it is deeply invigorating.”
